entry.title: How to Break Into Tech as a Self-Funded Newbie (While Juggling Family Responsibilities
entry.summary:
Breaking into the tech industry as a beginner is challenging enough—but what if you’re also self-funding your learning and supporting a family? Is there a realistic path to gaining skills, earning a stipend, and balancing responsibilities without burning out? Let’s be honest: there’s no true shortcut to becoming proficient in tech. However, with focus and the right approach, you can accelerate your growth while managing financial and family pressures. Here’s how: Start with Free/Low-Cost, High-Value Resources
Platforms like freeCodeCamp, The Odin Project, or CS50x (Harvard’s free intro to CS) offer structured, reputable curricula.
Supplement with YouTube tutorials (e.g., Traversy Media, Fireship) or affordable Udemy courses (wait for $10–$15 sales).
2. Earn While You Le…

entry.title: Como configurar deploy automático da sua API (GO) + Postgres com Docker via GitHub Actions e SSH
entry.summary: Nesta publicação, vou te mostrar passo a passo como estruturar seu projeto em Go, configurar o deploy automático com GitHub Actions e subir sua API — utilizando Docker. Ao final, você terá tudo rodando em um servidor remoto via SSH e realizando o deploy de forma automatizada. O projeto utilizado como exemplo é um CRUD simples de usuários, bancos e contas bancárias. Porém estruturado utilizando o padrão de arquitetura Ports and Adapters, também conhecido como Arquitetura Hexagonal. .github/ ├── workflows/ │ └── deploy.yml cmd/ ├── config/ │ └── database/ │ └── migrations/ └── main.go internal/ ├── core/ │ ├── domain/ │ │ ├── banco.go │ │ ├── conta.go │ │ └── usuario.go │ ├── dto/ │ │ ├── banco.go │ │ ├── conta.go │ │ └── usuario.go │ └── usecase/ │ …

entry.title: Games Workshop employees to receive £20m bonus
entry.summary: UK tabletop titan Games Workshop is splashing out a £20 million cash bonus to all staff after posting a 13% jump in core revenue (to £560 million) and a 20% rise in core profit (to £210 million) for the year to June 1, 2025. With roughly 1,500 people at its Nottingham HQ, that works out at about £13,333 each—beating last year’s £18 million bonus—and full results land in the July 29, 2025 annual report.

This scoop comes courtesy of trusted leaker Daniel RPK, and if true, we might see Schafer leading the franchise when it hits theaters in March 2027.

entry.title: How does Agile Planning improve team productivity?
entry.summary:
Breaking Down Projects into Manageable Tasks
Agile Planning boosts productivity by dividing complex projects into smaller, more manageable tasks. Rather than tackling the entire project at once, teams focus on specific objectives within a short time frame, making it easier to allocate resources effectively and maintain focus. This granular approach ensures that progress is visible and measurable at every stage.
At the core of Agile Planning is the concept of sprints—short work cycles where teams set clear, achievable goals. By prioritizing objectives within each sprint, Agile enables teams to concentrate on delivering the most valuable features first. This structured prioritization prevents teams from feeling overwhelmed and ensures that their efforts align with the most critical business needs. Agile Planning emphasizes ongoing communication among team members. Daily stand-up meetings, sprint planning sessions, and reviews ensure that everyone is aligned and aware of project developments. This frequent interaction helps address issues early, avoid misunderstandings, and maintain a high level of coordination throughout the project. A key strength of Agile Planning lies in its iterative nature. After each sprint, teams review their work, gather feedback, and refine their approach for the next cycle. This continuous improvement process helps identify what’s working and what needs adjustment, leading to more effective workflows and enhanced overall productivity.

entry.title: Star Wars Battlefront 2 devs want to ‘get the band back together' to make Battlefront 3
entry.summary: TL;DR: A former Star Wars Battlefront 2 dev, Mats Helge Holm, says he and “the rest of the gang” would love to reunite at EA and make Battlefront 3—especially now that a TikTok/Reddit revival has given the 2017 shooter a second wind. You might remember how Battlefront 2’s launch microtransactions nearly blew up the galaxy (40 hours of grinding to unlock Darth Vader, ugh). EA backpedaled, ditched paid loot boxes, kept adding freebies, and eventually sunsetted support in 2020. Now fans are flocking back—and the old dev crew is keen to ride that hype into a brand-new sequel.

entry.title: Nats vs Kafka
entry.summary:
If you're building an event-driven architecture, you will probably ask yourself: NATS or Kafka? Nats is a lightweight, simple, and very fast messaging system. It's perfect for microservices communication, IoT, and low latency scenarios. Easy to set up and use Extremely low latency (millisecond) Supports pub/sub, request/reply, and streaming (with JetStream) No message persistency by default (JetStream adds it) Not ideal for long message storage or heavy reprocessing Kafka is a distributed streaming platform, great for large-scale data processing, event sourcing, and real-time analytics. High durability and scalability Strong support for message retention and replay Great integration with Big Data tools More complex to run (Zookeeper, brokers, configurations) Higher latency compared to nats
Feature NATS Kafka
Latency Very low Higher
Complexity Low High
Durability Optional (JetStream) Built-in
Delivery Guarantees At most once / At least once* At least once / Exactly once
Replay Capability Limited Strong
Scalability High (but different) Very high
Common Use Cases Microservices, IoT Analytics, Event Sourcing, ETL
You need low latency and fast communication Your events are simples and short-lived You want a light and easy messaging system You need long-term retention and message replay Event are part of your business logic (event sourcing) You deal with large amounts of data There’s no one-size-fits-all. The right tool depends on your specific needs. NATS for fast and lightweight systems. Kafka for robust and scalable systems with high durability.

entry.title: Warhammer 40,000 Maker Games Workshop Is Doing So Well It's Giving $27 Million to Its Staff
entry.summary: TL;DR: Warhammer 40,000-maker Games Workshop just handed out a massive £20 million (≈$27 million) bonus to its ~1,500 staff—about £13,333 each—after posting record results. Over the year to June 2025, core revenues jumped to £560 million (from £494.7 million), licensing revenues hit £50 million (up from £31 million), and pre-tax profits climbed to £255 million (versus £203 million). Beyond its legendary tabletop miniatures, Games Workshop is cashing in big on IP: hit video games like Space Marine 2, animated shows (Secret Level), and an upcoming Henry Cavill-produced Warhammer 40K cinematic universe. While it warns licensing won’t keep growing at this pace, the company insists it’s bigger and stronger than ever—and it’s already teasing more expansions, from Space Marine 3 to a Dawn of War Definitive Edition.

entry.title: This giant microwave may change the future of war
entry.summary: Imagine: China deploys hundreds of thousands of autonomous drones in the air, on the sea, and under the water—all armed with explosive warheads or small missiles. These machines descend in a swarm toward military installations on Taiwan and nearby US bases, and over the course of a few hours, a single robotic blitzkrieg overwhelms the US…

entry.title: This startup wants to make more climate-friendly metal in the US
